results.title: Keepin' silent
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This compilation of footage from Australia’s silent era (1896-1930) encompasses examples of actuality, documentary, newsreels, home movies, advertisements, animation, narrative shorts and features. With piano accompaniment by Mrs Betty Magner.

results.title: Keepers of wildlife
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, George Pearson and Michael McKennirey
results.brief_description: Canada’s wilderness areas harbor some of the last remaining species of North American wildlife. This film shows what is being done by specialists of the Canadian Wildlife Service to prevent further depletion of their numbers. It is an enormous program of tabulating, banding, tagging, and, in the case of larger animals such as the bear and the buffalo, giving health check-ups. An engrossing film for any audience, replete with close-ups of animals, waterfowl, and fish.

results.title: Keepers of the mystery
results.brief_description: A Poetic travellogue of Scotland, documenting the distillation process of whisky on an industrial level, including barrel construction, blending, tasting (malt whisky and grain whiskey), Packaging and distribution. The film ends with a charming animated commercial for Whitehorse Cellar Scotch Whisky.

results.title: Keep the river on your right [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Next Wave Films, Lifer Films, David Shapiro and Laurie Shapiro
results.brief_description: Keep the river on your right is a fascinating documentary about anthropologist Tobias Schneebaum, a New York native who in the year 1955 (aged 34) travelled to Peru to study the tribes people there. Schneebaum’s experiences garnered him notoriety upon his return - he lived with the tribes and even partook in a cannibalistic raid on another village. This documentary tracks Schneebaum’s visit to that same village 45 years later, displaying his ambivalence about returning there. Archival footage of Schneebaum appearing on numerous chat shows does much to display the cultural imperialism of American attitudes as well as Schneebaum’s own sensitive views towards those he studied. Schneebaum, an author and artist of some repute is also shown lecturing on the Asmat tribe of Papua New Guinea, who openly embrace bisexuality as a way of life. On a study tour there, Schneebaum (who is gay) had a lover, with whom as a much older man he is reunited. This documentary has some scenes, including a male circumcision, which may disturb some viewers.

results.title: Keep moving
results.brief_description: Experimental narrative without dialogue using a mix of still images, animation and live action to describe alienation and encounters in a big city. Two characters walk, run and gaze across an industrial-looking street-end over which trains pass constantly. No motivation is given for their actions, nor is any definitive direction or conclusion reached. Rather, by a constant shifting of viewpoint and variation in the treatment of the images, the repeated actions focus the attention on movement itself, and on the barely perceptible changes that result.

results.title: Keep it green
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and Antonio Colacino
results.brief_description: One-third of the world’s agricultural production is destroyed each year by pests and diseases. Geographical isolation has helped protect Australia so far, but with increasing frequency and speed of modern communication the risk of their accidental introduction becomes greater every year. Plant Quarantine Inspectors check cargoes and passengers’ baggage, as they come into the country. Within industries such as sugar and rice, scientists work to improve commercial varieties and reduce disease.

results.title: Keep in the swim
results.creator_credit: Movietonenews and Australian Road Safety Council
results.brief_description: The need to obey rules to insure safety on the roads is illustrated by pictures of good and bad driving. The lesson is reinforced by shots of the champion swimmers Jon and Ilsa Konrads who in their training to become champions have to follow rules set out by the laws of swimming.

results.title: Keep fit, study well, work hard
results.brief_description: Contrasts schooling in China, where the stress is on discipline and group activities, with schools in the United States. Uses an admonition of Mao Tse Tung’s “keep fit, study well, and work hard”.
